posts.title: CSS Architecture for Scale
posts.excerpt: Best practices for organizing and scaling your CSS in large projects using modern methodologies like BEM, ITCSS, and design tokens.

content.text: As web applications grow in complexity, maintaining a scalable and maintainable CSS architecture becomes crucial. Poorly organized CSS can lead to specificity wars, bloated file sizes, and maintenance nightmares.
Methodologies for Scalable CSS
Several methodologies have emerged to help developers structure their CSS in a predictable and scalable way:

items: BEM (Block Element Modifier) - A naming convention that makes relationships clear
ITCSS (Inverted Triangle CSS) - Organizes CSS from generic to explicit
OOCSS (Object-Oriented CSS) - Separates structure from skin
SMACSS (Scalable and Modular Architecture for CSS) - Categorizes CSS rules

content.text: Implementing Design Tokens
Design tokens are the visual design atoms of your design system — specifically, they are named entities that store visual design attributes.

A well-structured CSS architecture should be predictable, maintainable, and scalable. It should allow multiple developers to work on the same codebase without conflicts.
Best Practices
Follow these principles for better CSS architecture:

items: Use a consistent naming convention throughout your project
Organize your CSS files logically (components, utilities, layouts)
Leverage CSS custom properties for theming and consistency
Keep specificity low to avoid override issues
Document your architecture decisions for team members

content.text: By implementing these strategies, you'll create a CSS architecture that scales with your project and remains maintainable over time.

posts.title: Building Accessible Web Applications
posts.excerpt: A deep dive into web accessibility principles and how to implement them in your projects to create inclusive user experiences.

content.text: Web accessibility ensures that people with disabilities can perceive, understand, navigate, and interact with websites and tools. It's not just a nice-to-have feature—it's a fundamental aspect of modern web development.
Understanding WCAG Guidelines
The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) provide a framework for making web content more accessible. The guidelines are organized around four principles:

items: Perceivable - Information and user interface components must be presentable to users in ways they can perceive
Operable - User interface components and navigation must be operable
Understandable - Information and the operation of user interface must be understandable
Robust - Content must be robust enough to be interpreted reliably by a wide variety of user agents

content.text: Essential Accessibility Features
Here are some key accessibility features every web application should implement:

items: Semantic HTML - Use proper HTML elements for their intended purpose
Keyboard Navigation - Ensure all functionality is available via keyboard
ARIA Labels - Provide additional context for screen readers
Color Contrast - Maintain sufficient contrast ratios for text
Focus Indicators - Make focus states visible and clear
Alt Text - Provide descriptive alt text for images

content.text: Accessibility is not a feature—it's a fundamental characteristic of good design. When we design for accessibility, we design for everyone.
Testing for Accessibility
Regular accessibility testing should be part of your development workflow:

items: Use automated tools like axe-core or Lighthouse
Conduct manual keyboard navigation testing
Test with screen readers (NVDA, VoiceOver, JAWS)
Check color contrast ratios
Validate HTML semantics and structure

content.text: Remember that accessibility is an ongoing process, not a one-time checklist. Continuously test and improve your application's accessibility to ensure it remains inclusive for all users.
